snippet: As the fight against terrorism broadens to Africa, the United States faces a tricky balance: how to fight an enemy without actually doing the fighting.
abstract: Eliza Griswold article explains how America's changing strategy to fight against terrorism, which has been broadened to include Africa, is coming to rely on small groups of Special Operations forces offering military aid and advice; notes change is primarily driven by desire on part of the United States to fight terrorists without doing much actual fighting.
lead_paragraph: As the fight against terrorism broadens to Africa, the United States faces a tricky balance: how to fight an enemy without actually doing the fighting.

headline.main: Can General Linder’s Special Operations Forces Stop the Next Terrorist Threat?
